instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-3437: What is 820-3437? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.ALL_SYS_PWRGD: What is ALL_SYS_PWRGD? ALL_SYS_PWRGD is present when PP1V8_S3, PP5V_S3, PP1V2_S3, PP1V05_S0, PP5V_S0, PP3V3_S0, & PP1V5_S0 are present and working. If any of these rails is not working, ALL_SYS_PWRGD will be pulled down and the machine will not turn on. .
definitions.PP5V_S0: What is PP5V_S0? PP5V_S0 is a 5v power rail present when the system is in an S0 working state..
definitions.PP3V3_S0: What is PP3V3_S0? The "PP3V3_S0" rail in a MacBook logic board is a power rail that supplies 3.3 volts to the system when it is fully awake (S0 state). .
definitions.PP1V5_S0: What is PP1V5_S0? PP1V5_S0 is a 1.5v power rail present when the machine is in an S0 working state.
definitions.P1V8S3_PGOOD: What is P1V8S3_PGOOD? P1V8S3_PGOOD is a signal that denotes that the PP1V8_S3 power rail is working..
definitions.P5VS4RS3_PGOOD: What is P5VS4RS3_PGOOD? P5VS4RS3_PGOOD is a signal that confirms the PP5V_S4RS3 power rail is working properly. .

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> missing cpu core
threads.message:
This board is liquide damage arround <CHIP>U7870</CHIP> and resistors. Pulsing. Only S5 voltage present

I removed <RESISTOR>R8167</RESISTOR> and I have all coils present volatge but no cpu core.
<CHIP>U7870</CHIP> generate 1.5V stable.
<CHIP>U3210</CHIP> looks good no corrosion there. Far from corrosion.

<RESISTOR>R8162</RESISTOR> no istalled on this board and 0V on both pins.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> missing cpu core
threads.message:
<SIGNAL>ALL_SYS_PWRGD</SIGNAL> & <SIGNAL>PM_PCH_SYS_PWROK</SIGNAL> high when in S0 state, if on both pins of <RESISTOR>R8162</RESISTOR> is 0V I assume its low? Check if <SIGNAL>PP5V_S0</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S0</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>PP1V5_S0</SIGNAL> is there
Verify around <TRANSISTOR>Q8150</TRANSISTOR> area. If all these S0 voltages are there check if the resistors are working within specifications (<RESISTOR>R8151</RESISTOR>-<RESISTOR>R8159</RESISTOR>)

If the system is pulsing in and out of S0-->S5-->S0 check for a short on all S0 lines

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> missing cpu core
threads.message:
I think you dont understand what I did.

1. Board pulsing but I removed <RESISTOR>R8167</RESISTOR> and now NOT pulsing anymore. 

2. I have all rails 5V, 1.2V and 1.05 present.

3. CPU missing

These rails appear only when I removed <RESISTOR>R8167</RESISTOR>. What that means?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> missing cpu core
threads.message:
<SIGNAL>P1V8S3_PGOOD</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>P5VS4RS3_PGOOD</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>P1V05S0_PGOOD</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>DDRREG_PGOOD</SIGNAL> high?

Do you have <SIGNAL>ALL_SYS_PWRGD</SIGNAL> & <SIGNAL>PM_PCH_SYS_PWROK</SIGNAL> high at the moment? As that could explain why the cpu vcore would not activate

I'm a bit confused on why removing <RESISTOR>R8167</RESISTOR> would solve the no S0. As far as I can see <RESISTOR>R8167</RESISTOR> is a pull-up resistor for the <SIGNAL>ALL_SYS_PWRGD</SIGNAL> line. I'd recommend getting it back on. You might not be able to see the _PGOOD lines being high or low without it

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> missing cpu core
threads.message: Is <SIGNAL>ALL_SYS_PWRGD</SIGNAL> present with <RESISTOR>R8167</RESISTOR> on the board? Why did you remove this?
